en: Interview with Steve Norman, ecologist with the United States Forest Service, conducted by Ken Wise. Norman discusses the causes of the wildfires and the potential for more fires in the future. Conducted over Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is a representative quote from the interview: You've got a whole lot of homes on the way that were not there back in the day of Wiley Oakley. And so the hazard might be the same over the centuries, but the vulnerability, the susceptible assets we have, and therefore the risk, are quite a bit different now than they ever were in the past.

And so the hazard might be the same over the centuries, but the vulnerability, the susceptible assets we have, and therefore the risk, are quite a bit different now than they ever were in the past.

Interview with Steve Norman, 2020-06-11 -- Great Smoky Mountains
Can you state your name and share some of your background and area of research?
When did you first become aware of the fire on the Chimneys?
When did yo hear the news that the fire had reached Gatlinburg?
Based upon your research, can you describe what happened for the climate to create such a catastrophe?
Can you describe what the mountain wave phenomenon is?
Why did the fire move from the Chimney Tops after a week? Why did the fire skip around instead of being uniform?
Would the pattern of the ember rain explain why downtown Gatlinburg suffered very little fire?
Did you get a chance to view the damage in the park after the fire?
What did the destruction in the mountains look like?
What do you think may happen with the next fire? Will it be similar or different?
Some believe before the fire spread on Monday, that it could have been extinguished, would that have been feasible?
Can you frame your research in how it applies and should be understood by the general public?
How would you assess your research on the discipline's understanding of this fire?
Did you see anything good that came out of this fire?
Was there anything that surprised you in the fire event?
Is there anything that we haven't covered that you would like to share?

seo.title: Interview with Steve Norman, 2020-06-11 - Rising From the Ashes Oral Histories
seo.description: Interview with Steve Norman, ecologist with the United States Forest Service, conducted by Ken Wise. Norman discusses the causes of the wildfires and the potential for more fires in the future. Conducted over Zoom due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This is a representative quote from the interview: You've got a whole lot of homes on the way that were not there back in the day of Wiley Oakley. And so the hazard might be the same over the centuries, but the vulnerability, the susceptible assets we have, and therefore the risk, are quite a bit different now than they ever were in the past.
